rules.title: Use Consistent Terminology
rules.description: Use the same term consistently to refer to the same concept throughout a document or product.
rules.example_incorrect: Click the 'Start' button in one place and 'Begin' button in another for the same function.
rules.example_correct: Click the 'Start' button everywhere it refers to the same action.

rules.title: Prefer Industry-Standard Terms
rules.description: Use terminology that is widely recognized within the industry or technology domain.
rules.example_incorrect: Use 'shutdown script' when the industry term is 'termination script'.
rules.example_correct: Use 'termination script' to align with industry standards.

rules.title: Avoid Jargon When Possible
rules.description: Replace specialized or internal jargon with plain language unless the target audience is guaranteed to understand it.
rules.example_incorrect: We’ll refactor the CRUD endpoints in the microservice.
rules.example_correct: We’ll update the create, read, update, and delete operations in the service.

rules.title: Define New or Specialized Terms
rules.description: Introduce and define terms the first time they appear, especially if they are technical or product-specific.
rules.example_incorrect: Use the SLA settings to adjust response time requirements.
rules.example_correct: Use the Service Level Agreement (SLA) settings to adjust response time requirements.

rules.title: Use Singular Nouns for Concepts
rules.description: When referring to a concept as a category, use singular form unless referring to multiple distinct items.
rules.example_incorrect: The softwares are installed on all devices.
rules.example_correct: The software is installed on all devices.

rules.title: Avoid Redundant Terms
rules.description: Do not use words that duplicate meaning already implied by other words.

rules.title: Follow Product Terminology Guidelines
rules.description: If your product or organization has an approved terminology list, follow it exactly for spelling, capitalization, and phrasing.
